territory.notes: On April 24, 1884, Germany formally declared “Lüderitzland” to be a protectorate of the German Empire. Initially, the extent of German control was only a small area around Lüderitz Bay. Through a series of purchases and “protective treaties” with African leaders in 1884-1885, Germany declared an expanded German protectorate over not just Lüderitz Bay and the coastal areas, but also the Red Nation, Great Namaqualand, Hereroland, and other tribes (such as the Damara) and geographic areas extending over the southern and central portions of present-day Namibia. A German Commissioner was appointed in August 1885, which may have coincided with the first use of the name, German South West Africa. Representatives of the Namibian tribal nations, however, did not interpret the treaties to mean a relinquishment of their sovereignty, and subsequently renounced some of the agreements (e.g., in 1888 the Hereros renounced their 1885 protectorate agreement with Germany). Between 1886 and 1890 Germany entered into agreements with Portugal and Britain that established the colonial boundaries of present-day Namibia, and Germany laid claim to and officially annexed the entire area in 1890, after bringing in military troops a year earlier. Through the early to mid-1890’s, German troops fought various Nama, Herero, and Orlams groups in an effort to solidify German claims to the colony, eventually succeeding by 1896, in some instances with the assistance of treaties (such as the German treaty with Hendrik Witbooi on behalf of the Orlam Namas). Renewed Herero and Nama uprisings occurred between 1903-1907 (especially 1904), which were eventually put down after a brutal German military campaign of extermination in which 80% of the Herero population was killed. Later, Germany faced continued challenges to its sovereignty in the northern parts of the colony, including from the Portuguese. In 1908 German officials signed treaties with several Ovambo groups in northern Namibia. In the context of WWI, South African troops invaded and occupied German South West Africa from 1914 to 1915. The German forces surrendered to the South Africans at the peace of Khorab on July 9, 1915, and South Africa imposed martial law on the same date. On December 7, 1920, in the context of the Treaty of Versailles, South West Africa was officially designated a League of Nations Class C mandate, to be administered by South Africa on behalf of the British crown (given South Africa’s status as a British dominion). Following WWII and the termination of the League of Nations, the South African Government asserted that the League of Nations mandate had expired, refusing to submit South West Africa to the new United Nations Trusteeship system. South Africa claimed sole authority over South West Africa following the demise of the League of Nations. In the 1960’s, the name Namibia was increasingly used outside South Africa to refer to South West Africa, reflecting increasing international criticism of South Africa’s refusal to grant independence to Namibia/South West Africa. Namibia became independent on March 21, 1990.
